intro: Laphamia dissecta, commonly known as the dissected lichen, is a species of lichen that belongs to the family Parmeliaceae. It is characterized by its intricate, leaf-like thallus with a distinctive, finely divided structure. The plant forms a symbiotic relationship between a fungus and a green alga or cyanobacterium, which allows it to thrive on rock surfaces in moist, shaded environments. Laphamia dissecta is typically found in temperate regions and is often used as an indicator of air quality due to its sensitivity to pollution. Its botanical features make it an important subject in ecological and lichenological studies.
